comment.comment: I wasn't a projectionist but spent enough time in the projection booth to know the "dots in the corner" system. Downside is when you're watching a movie, you can't "unsee" them. Upside is â¦ when you see the first one, you can tell your friend: "watch the top right corner of the screen â¦ you'll see a dot up there in 3, 2, 1 seconds".

group_comments_v2.title: Bryn Dyment commented on Adam Bell's post.

comment.comment: Tangentially related â¦ there's a pattern in English where the verb form is two words and the noun form one word. Applies to hundreds of words. ("Set up the printer." vs. "Nice computer setup you have there.", for example.) Often the adjective form is hyphenated: "Did you follow the set-up instructions?" I never learned this in school but I notice that lots of native speakers are unaware of this pattern and are constantly using the noun form as a verb. Drives me crazy but I have learned to keep quiet (except for here, now!).
comment.author: Bryn Dyment

group_comments_v2.title: Bryn Dyment commented on Suleiman Paz's post.

comment.comment: FWIW, I think there are many words in English that follow this general pattern. Verb form is two words and noun form one word. Adjective form is the same as noun form, or sometimes hyphenated. Sometimes the "verb form" and "noun form" aren't really that connected, though (e.g. "stand by your man" vs. "i'm on standby").
comment.author: Bryn Dyment
